The Chinese Church Grows Despite Persecution
Period: !!smallcaps|ad!! 1949–Present
Description: Despite years of violent oppression during the Cultural Revolution, the church in China grew rapidly through an underground movement.
The Chinese church continued to expand
Key Developments
The People's Republic of China was established by the Chinese Communist Party.
Under an atheist and anti-imperialist government, foreign missionaries were expelled.

The Chinese Communist Party established five national religious organizations, including the Protestant Three-Self Patriotic Movement, into which all Protestant denominations were merged, and the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.
Mao initiated the Cultural Revolution to rid Chinese society of any opposition to Chinese communism.
Churches and other places of worship were closed that contributed to foreign influence in China, including the Three-Self Patriotic Movement and the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.
Opponents were persecuted, including Christians; some were imprisoned.
The church in China moved underground, meeting in homes, and began to expand rapidly.
The Cultural Revolution came to an end following the death of Mao though resistance to religion still remained.
China began to open up to the world under new Communist leadership.
Churches were allowed to reopen.
Key People
Roman Catholics

Ignatius Kung Pin-Mei (August 2, 1901–March 12, 2000): Roman Catholic Bishop of Shanghai; opposed the Cultural Revolution in China and was imprisoned for 30 years; made cardinal by John Paul II in 1979.
Beda Chang (c. 1905–November 11, 1951): Chinese Jesuit priest; he was martyred under the communist government of the People's Republic of China.[^1]
Political Leaders

Mao Zedong (December 26, 1893–September 9, 1976): Chinese communist revolutionary; leader of the Chinese Communist Party; founder of the People's Republic of China; developed Maoism ideology influenced by Marxism-Leninism; author of the May 16 Notification which started the Cultural Revolution.

Deng Xiaoping (September 13, 1982–November 2, 1987): Chinese revolutionary; succeeded Mao as leader of the People's Republic of China; introduced reforms in China and relaxed governmental control over religion.

Gang of Four (20th century) was a group of four officials from the Communist Party of China who were leaders of the Cultural Revolution; they were sentenced to life in prison for crimes committed during the Cultural Revolution.
Protestants
Y. T. Wu: (November 4, 1893–September 17, 1979): Chinese Protestant leader; founded the Three-Self Patriotic Movement.
Tzu-ch’en Chao (1888-1979): Chinese Protestant leader and theologian; supporter of the Three-Self Patriotic Movement; signed The Christian Manifesto.
Watchman Nee (November 4, 1903–May 30, 1972): Chinese indigenous church leader and founder of the Local Church movement; he was arrested under communist rule and died as a prisoner.

K. H. Ting (September 20, 1915–November 22, 2012): Anglican Bishop of Zhejiang; Chinese statesman; Chairperson emeritus of the Three-Self Patriotic Movement; President emeritus of the China Christian Council.
Bible Translations
Chinese Union Version (1919): primary Chinese Bible translation used by Protestants in China.
Encyclicals

Cupimus imprimis (Pope Pius XII, 1952): papal encyclical written during the persecution of Chinese Christians in the People's Republic of China; offers encouragement to Chinese Catholics who remained faithful amidst persecution.

Ad Sinarum gentem (Pope Pius XII, 1954); papal encyclical written during the persecution of Chinese Christians in the People's Republic of China; offers encouragement to Chinese Catholics who remained faithful amidst persecution.

Ad Apostolorum principis (Pope Pius XII, 1958): papal encyclical written during the persecution of Chinese Christians in the People' Republic of China; criticizes the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association and offers encouragement to Chinese Catholics amidst persecution.
Governing Documents
Constitution of the People's Republic of China (1982): grants citizens freedom of religion; includes clause  "the State protects normal religious activities" (Article 36).[^2]
Manifestos
The Christian Manifesto (1950): written by Protestants in China; supported the People's Republic of China and the Communist Party of China.
May 16 Notification (Mao Zedong. 1966): circular issued during a meeting of the Chinese Communist Party in Beijing which launched the Cultural Revolution.

Beda Chang (c. 1905–November 11, 1951): Chinese Jesuit priest; he was martyred under the communist government of the People's Republic of China.[^1]
Key Events
1949: People’s Republic of China Is Established by the Chinese Communist Party
1950: People’s Republic of China Forces Missionaries to Leave
1952: Watchman Nee Is Arrested
1953: China Inland Mission Leaves China Under the People’s Republic
1954: The Three-Self Patriotic Movement Is Established
1957: The Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association Is Established
1966: Persecution of Christians in China; churches are closed.
1966–1969: Cultural Revolution in China is led by Mao Zedong to preserve communism and impose Maoism; churches and other religious institutions were closed.
1979: The US and China Re-Establish Diplomatic Relations
1979: Ignatius Kung Pin-Mei Is Made Cardinal by Pope Paul II
1980: Chinese Government Allows Printing of 50,000 New Testaments in Chinese
early 1980s: Church in China Begins Experiencing Significant Growth
1989: Tienanmen Square Protests
1991: China Christian Council Joins World Council of Churches
1991: Many Christians Are Arrested in China
1991: China Study Bible Is Published
2000: Christian Population in China Grows to 75 Million
2000: Pope John Paul II Canonizes 120 Chinese Catholic Martyrs
Key Places
Beijing is the capital of the People's Republic of China; the Cultural Revolution originated here.
China is part of the Global South; Christianity expanded here under Communist rule.
Shanghai is the location of Moore Memorial Church, the first church to reopen following the Cultural Revolution.
Key Concepts
Chinese Christian Council was established by the Protestant churches in China.
Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association is part of the state-sanctioned Chinese Church; not recognized by the Vatican.
Chung Hua Sheng Kung Hui was the Anglican Church in China which was merged into the Three-Self Patriotic Movement.
Communism attempted to suppress Christianity in China.
Maoism was developed by Mao Zedong as a type of communism.
Three-Self Patriotic Movement is part of the state-sanctioned Chinese Church; advocates for self-governance, self-support, and self-propagation; originally named the Three-Self Reform Movement.
